docs.lead_paragraph: THERE is a quiet confidence about Amy Callahan of Hoboken, N.J. She is 30 and petite, and she measures her words in a way that befits her profession as a special-education teacher in nearby Springfield. She occasionally stumbles, though, when speaking of Scott Hazelcorn. Mr. Hazelcorn was her fiancé, a 29-year-old bond broker at Cantor Fitzgerald who was killed in the World Trade Center attacks. She called him Haze. ''I'm having to call him Scott so much these days,'' she said. ''It's strange for me.''

headline.main: Dreams of a Summer Camp Take the Form of Reality

docs.abstract: Amy Callahan, whose fiance, Scott Hazelcorn, was killed in World Trade Center attacks, has created Scott Hazelcorn Children's Foundation with plans to open summer camp for children affected by that tragedy; says idea for summer camp grew out of conversation she and Hazelcorn had last summer, talking of their experiences as campers when they were children, and later as camp counselors; as news of foundation spreads, checks stream in, and relatives and friends are raising money at rallies and other events; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AT 9:02 a.m. on April 19, 1995, a bomb killed 168 people at the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building in Oklahoma City. The country's grief was both palpable and tangible. Americans responded by sending more than $40 million, trying to provide what succor they could to the families of the victims. None of the local charities had ever administered such sums before, so they learned as they went along. The Oklahoma City Community Foundation, which usually manages money donated for improving the city, quickly took the lead in coordinating the relief efforts. Now New York's charities face similar challenges and pitfalls, albeit on a much larger scale. In a recent interview, Nancy B. Anthony, the Oklahoma City foundation's executive director, was asked to recap some of her experiences in the Oklahoma disaster and explain what she had learned. Q. Why did your group wind up leading the relief effort in Oklahoma? A. We hadn't planned to. But banks, fraternal groups, civic do-gooders, everyone and their uncle wanted to set up a fund, and few of them understood how to qualify as a charity under I.R.S. rules. For example, they didn't realize that you can't just start writing out checks, you have to actually document needs. We distributed a memo explaining the rules. When people realized it took more than just collecting money, many asked us to set up their funds. By the end of two weeks, we were handling 10 funds, including the governor's and the mayor's. Q. How much money was collected for the relief effort? A. About $400,000 at first, but after a few months we were in the million-dollar area, as we inherited a lot more stand-alone funds. We eventually wound up administering about $15 million, more than a third of all the donations that came in. Q. Didn't the funds bridle at the idea that their contributions would be thrown into a big pot? Didn't they want credit for their donations, and a say in how their funds were spent? A. We didn't take money unless the funds gave us discretion to dispense it. And they had to realize that recipients didn't care who paid their medical bills, just that the bills were paid. But we spent the governor's and mayor's funds first, since the political officials were under pressure from the media to prove they were using the dollars they collected. After that, we identified donors in rotation -- if we made one grant in the name of the Rotary Club, the next one would be from the Kiwanis Club. Q. How did you set your priorities for spending the money? A. First, we let the Red Cross and the Federal Emergency Management Agency folks deal with immediate emergency issues like travel expenses for family members. That bought us time to get organized. Also, about 60 percent of those killed worked for the federal government, and their families were eligible for federal relief. Many others had savings and family members who could help. So, we first dealt with those who needed immediate help paying utility bills and mortgages. And we coordinated with the Red Cross and other charities to set up a case manager system so that every family dealing with a death or critical injury was assigned someone trained in social work to be their advocate. At first, we thought that the social workers already working for the charities could handle that, but it didn't work. People who were trained to deal with chronic poverty or substance abuse weren't trained for this kind of work. So, we subcontracted some of the case management to people who were trained to assess a family's debts, to help them get death certificates, to navigate the system of benefits and issues specifically related to the Oklahoma City bombing. Q. How did you make sure that you and other charities weren't making duplicate grants, and that the recipients really were needy? A. We didn't just hand money to people, we paid their bills. When you are paying one electric or grocery bill at a time, you're not terribly concerned about fraud. Our bigger concern was getting people into counseling to get through the grieving process. And all of the relief organizations operated a joint database in which we shared data about people who were applying for help. The reason was to cut bureaucracy, so that if someone filled out the paperwork at the Salvation Army, they didn't have to fill it out again for us. But it also created an electronic file of who was getting what. The case managers, meanwhile, checked what needs were already being met by community groups. If a homebound elder was getting hot meals delivered before the bombing, he doesn't need more because his son died. Children who were already receiving Medicaid didn't need us to pick up medical costs. One man lost his wife and his car in the bombing. His church bought him a new car; we paid for the title and tax. Q. You faced criticism from the media on the way grants were disbursed. How did you handle that? A. We kept the money separate from the rest of our charitable funds. We never allocated any portion of our overhead to it, or deducted any administrative expenses from it. And we kept excellent records, so that we could verify how we used every penny. Q. Yet, the criticism kept coming. Why? A. Disgruntled people make great stories for the media. There's a culture of victimhood, made up of people whose identity as Victim of the Oklahoma City Bombing gave them an importance and visibility they never had before. Suddenly there'd be this story about some guy with four kids whose wife was killed, who couldn't pay his bills and who wasn't getting helped. In fact, we'd probably done a great deal for this guy, but we'd all agreed to keep our database totally confidential, so we couldn't respond. Also, people didn't understand what the money has to cover. People would hear about huge insurance settlements and such, and they'd think the money we collected was supposed to compensate the families of the 168 people who were killed. They forgot that these are funds to meet specific needs, not to compensate all victims for their loss. And they forgot that many of the survivors needed help, too. We paid medical bills for 83 people with serious injuries. One lady whose legs were crushed had a hospital bill of half a million dollars. Many of the survivors still have significant living and medical expenses, and huge mental health problems. There is a little boy who still has metal in his head, a man who still has glass in his body, others who were blinded. We have a staff person who still spends half her time working with families that are still emotionally dysfunctional. And we earmarked about $7 million for scholarship funds for any child whose parent was lost or disabled. We still have two-thirds of that money left, but even though it is not spent, it is committed. Q. So, even now, you're still administering money related to the bombing. Are you still collecting it? A. We stopped actively soliciting funds after a year, but money still comes in. For example, we still get checks from publishers who had earmarked a portion of the proceeds from books about the bombing. And remember, we do still have scholarships to pay out, and emotional counseling to do. But the actual bombing-related work is winding down. We knew our database of survivors wasn't year 2000 compliant, and would be wiped out at the beginning of that year. We did nothing to prevent that. The I.R.S. rules do say that, even if a donor earmarks funds for a particular use, the receiving charity can use the dollars in any way that is consistent with its stated mission. It would be completely legal for us to use extra money from the Oklahoma City bombing to provide relief to victims of the many tornados we have in this area. But it's probably not a good idea to do that when you're still asking people to give money for a specific need. The Red Cross is running into that in New York now. They've said they'll use some of the money they've collected to expand services related to other terrorist events. Maybe that makes sense in three years, if there's nothing that still needs doing in New York, but I'm not sure they should be doing this now. Q. Looking back, are there things you should have done differently? A. We should have relieved the pressure on our own people. They were working 12-hour days, and we should have made sure they took lunch breaks and time for diversion. Anger is a stage in the process of grieving, and sometimes, as unfair as it was, we became the object of that anger. We should have trained our own people to deal with that anger without getting angry back.

headline.main: Helping After Terror: Oklahoma City's Lessons

docs.lead_paragraph: Zhang Jianqi remembers the doctor's advice at the rural Sui Xian County hospital in central China when they told him this summer that his 8-year-old daughter, plagued by constant fevers, had tested positive for H.I.V. ''They said, 'Don't tell anyone, because no one will play with her,' '' Mr. Zhang recalled from the narrow bed he now shares with the girl, his sick middle child, Xiaqing, who listened shyly from the doorway of their one-room shanty.

headline.main: AIDS Patients in China Lack Effective Treatment

docs.abstract: Article in series, Silent Plague: Patients Without Hope, examining China's efforts to cope with explosion of AIDS cases, many brought on by poor medical practices; hundreds of thousands of Chinese suffering from HIV are receiving little or nothing in way of care; part of problem is prohibitively high cost of new drugs that make up 'AIDS cocktail' that is commonly used in West and whose patents are jealously guarded by Western drug companies; even most of older, cheaper drugs used widely elsewhere for more than decade to prevent and treat infections to which those with HIV are susceptible are only rarely available in China, and there is little national effort to educate doctors about disease; critics say underlying problem is that government has chosen to abandon patients who suffer from disease that it still regards as embarrassment and is refusing to follow example of many other countries in purchasing or making cheaper generic versions of drugs used in HIV care even though China has large and capable pharmaceutical industry; photos (M)

headline.main: Help for Careers That Require Heavy Lifting

docs.abstract: Profile of Hard Hatted Women, group founded in Cleveland in 1979, whose mission is to promote women's access to nontraditional jobs in fields like steelwork and construction; group offers education, advocacy and employment placement services as well as preapprenticeship training programs; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The radical act of the terrorists opens a space for us to think radically as well. While many of the billions that will be available for rebuilding -- from insurance, from federal aid, from city coffers, from developers -- are surely needed to restore the health and character of Lower Manhattan, it seems reasonable to question whether such massive expenditure should be focused exclusively downtown rather than throughout the city at sites of need and opportunity. Although many think of Manhattan and New York City as one and the same, the majority of the city's population and geography do not lie on the island: Manhattan holds only 6.8 percent of the city's land area and 19 percent of its inhabitants. It is, however, our economic motor, accounting for two-thirds of New York City's jobs and almost half its retail sales. The great infusions of capital and the artificial fortunes of the last decade have propelled the price of real estate in much of Manhattan to stratospheric heights, accelerating the flight of the middle class and the poor and making Manhattan increasingly monochrome, the differences among its neighborhoods merely physical. While our ethnic and cultural quarters solidify and thrive outside the borough -- in Flushing, Astoria, the new bohemias of Dumbo, Williamsburg and Long Island City, and along Atlantic Avenue -- Manhattan becomes a place of privilege, inhospitible to striving, less and less like New York.

headline.main: [RETHINK]: Manifestoes For the Next New York; [Boroughs]: Put a Piece of Downtown in Flushing

docs.abstract: Michael Sorkin article suggests Sept 11 terrorist attack offers opportunity to transform New York City by thrusting neighborhoods of other boroughs into forefront; building smaller centers of office space that would benefit boroughs with Manhattan at epicenter would reinforce New York's diversity and better utilize extensive talent; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For much of the 20th century, a Manhattan neighborhood called Inwood reigned as the unofficial capital of the Irish diaspora, and in its later years, an elderly Jewish man and a young Irish kid from the Good Shepherd school had their own daily ritual. After school let out, Damian Meehan and a small legion of kids would come ganging down 207th Street, past the ramshackle fruit store where Sam Gategno and his brother Sando presided, often perched on the sidewalk thrones of milk crates.
docs.abstract: Article discusses heavy toll of World Trade Center attack on Irish-American community in New York, focusing on Damian Meehan, whose family settled in Inwood section of Manhattan when they emigrated from Ireland; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: LAST spring, when Congress was debating President Bush's $1.35 trillion tax cut, many Democrats warned that the amount was too big, that the reduction left no buffer for unexpected bad news and would ultimately lead to spending cuts. In many ways, they have already been proved right.

headline.main: A Deficit Ahead, Many Forks In the Road

docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time in decades, America's heroes are everyday working people: firemen, postal workers, E.M.S. technicians, police officers, soldiers. In celebrity magazines, iron welders appear, in their beefy union T-shirts, like movie stars, and outside the city's firehouses, crowds continue to linger -- the buckets of flowers still fresh, the candles still lighted. As David Letterman said, summing up the nation's sense of gratitude: ''I hope we never, ever take these people for granted.'' If ever there was a moment for the revival of organized labor, it is now. Yet Congress and corporate America seem shockingly unattuned to this extraordinary shift in the national mood. Of the government's $15 billion bailout of the airlines, not one cent went to laid-off workers. Only 2.3 percent of the House of Representatives' $100 billion ''stimulus'' package went to extending unemployment and health insurance to the more than half a million newly unemployed. And because the rules governing such programs have not kept pace with the changing face of labor, vast sectors of working-class Americans -- especially the immigrants and single working parents in part-time, seasonal and minimum-wage service jobs -- won't qualify for even this meager aid. In many states, even legal immigrants are denied assistance, and welfare caps are kicking in at just the wrong moment.

headline.main: [RETHINK]: Manifestoes For the Next New York; [Labor]: Capitalize on Blue-Collar Heroism

docs.lead_paragraph: WHENEVER the economy begins growing again -- be it early next year, if the recession is an average one, or many months later, if not -- the next expansion will probably have a character starkly different from those of the recent past. For the last few months, the business of keeping people healthy has been one of the only parts of the $10 trillion American economy that has remained healthy, and many economists now say that the sprawling health care industry may be the only driver of growth in the near term. Even when consumer spending and corporate investment pick up, the health care sector is likely to expand faster than most industries in the years ahead.

headline.main: Health Care As Main Engine: Is That So Bad?

docs.lead_paragraph: Dealing with what happened to our city on Sept. 11 has involved a kind of progression, and for many of us, the initial phase included some level of incomprehension. One of the stranger images left in my head from that terrible morning is of a woman standing on my corner in TriBeCa, laughing into her cellphone. Survivors, many of them coated head to foot with ash, were processing mutely up Church Street. My wife and I had run outside to determine whether we should evacuate the children from our apartment. And this nicely dressed woman was chatting with a friend as if New York were the same city it had been an hour earlier. Perhaps this was simply some kind of hysterical reaction. But I think that on that day, and for days afterward, all of us faced in varying degrees the difficulty of wrapping our minds around the magnitude of the murderous destruction visited on the place we live. For New York as a whole, disbelief and denial soon gave way to comprehension and grief. The uncountable dead were enumerated. Their killers acquired an identity. And in our public and personal ways, we mourned our losses. Some of us went to funerals and memorial services. Others joined impromptu wakes at firehouses around the city. Some just watched CNN and wept.
docs.abstract: Jacob Weisberg article contends that New York after Sept 11 attack is different city than it was before, and that there is bittersweet opportunity to make it better through rebuilding; says it makes no sense to consider disaster site in isolation, that in deciding what to put there, one must think of entire city, its needs, feelings and potential; says connection between catastrophe and progress is essential to city's history, and cites examples of previous growth from ashes of calamity; discusses contributions to infrastructure by Robert Moses, as well as opposition to Moses's plans by Jane Jacobs, who spawned community-based movement that celebrated neighborhoods as heart of city; says World Trade Center was type of development Jacobs and others objected to and that it was not financially successful project; says office space lost on Sept 11 is actually no longer needed, largely due to electronic communications; says goal should be to restore sense of opportunity for city's poor as well as enhance city as global cultural attraction; concedes rebuilding will be difficult, but newly-found civic personality should be harnessed to benefit restoration process (M)
